title: 109_s993
content: Excise tax is imposed on acquisitions of interests in insurance contracts where certain exempt organizations hold an interest, as per Section 4965 of the Internal Revenue Code. Excise tax of 100 percent is imposed on the acquisition costs of any interest in an applicable insurance contract by certain exempt organizations or other individuals, as defined in Section 4965 of the Internal Revenue Code. The excise tax of 100 percent applies to the acquisition costs of an interest in an applicable insurance contract by exempt organizations or individuals as per Section 4965 of the Internal Revenue Code. The term "applicable insurance contract" excludes life insurance, annuity, or endowment contracts under certain exceptions. The excise tax of 100 percent applies to acquisition costs of an interest in an applicable insurance contract by exempt organizations or individuals under Section 4965 of the Internal Revenue Code. Acquisition costs include direct or indirect costs of acquiring the contract. The excise tax of 100 percent applies to acquisition costs of an interest in an applicable insurance contract by exempt organizations or individuals under Section 4965 of the Internal Revenue Code. This includes fees, commissions, charges, or other amounts paid in connection with the acquisition, regardless of the payee. Timing of payments is important, with the tax imposed each time costs are paid or incurred over multiple calendar years. An interest in the contract encompasses any rights related to it, whether as an owner, beneficiary, or otherwise, including indirect interests in entities holding the contract. In the context of applicable insurance contracts, any interest in the contracts involved in an exchange is treated as an interest in all contracts. Increasing an interest in such a contract is considered a separate acquisition. Acquiring an interest before it becomes applicable is taxable once it becomes applicable. Applicable exempt organizations include those described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The tax imposed by this section shall not be included in investment in the contract. Regulations may exempt certain contracts from treatment as insurance contracts based on specific factors and provide appropriate rules for the application of this section. The Secretary may prevent abuse in cases deemed necessary. The tax imposed by this section aims to prevent multiple taxes on the same interest and avoid avoidance of the section's purposes. A conforming amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 42 of the Code. "Reporting Requirements. Subpart B of part III of subchapter A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section, SEC. 6050U, for returns related to applicable insurance contracts held by certain exempt organizations." The new section SEC. 6050U requires exempt organizations and other persons acquiring interests in applicable insurance contracts to make returns as specified. Time for filing the return will be determined by the Secretary. The new section SEC. 6050U mandates exempt organizations and individuals acquiring interests in applicable insurance contracts to file returns with specific details, as determined by the Secretary, including acquisition years and transfer years. The returns must be in the prescribed form and include relevant taxpayer information. The returns required under section 6050U must include information on the person acquiring an interest in the insurance contract, the exempt organization holding an interest, and the issuer of the contract. The returns should also contain the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of the transferor and transferee, along with other details as prescribed by the Secretary. Additionally, individuals making these returns must provide a written statement to each person whose taxpayer information is included, showing the name, address, and contact information of the person required to make the return, as well as the necessary taxpayer identity information. The written statement required for returns under section 6050U must be provided to the person by the specified date. Penalties for non-compliance are outlined in section 6724(d) of the Code. The amendment adds a new subparagraph (E) to section 6050U regarding returns related to insurance contracts held by exempt organizations. It also amends section 6721(e)(2) to include penalties for intentional disregard of tax payments under section 4965. The amendment adds a new item to subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Code. The amendment adds a new item to subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Code, relating to applicable insurance contracts held by exempt organizations. The amendments apply to contracts issued after May 3, 2005, with reporting requirements for existing contracts held by exempt organizations. The Secretary shall submit reports to the Committees on Ways and Means and Finance within 6 months, including recommendations for legislation.
